description.raw:
BulletHingeJoint [doesn't fully support joint limits outside of (-pi,pi)](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/issues/42). If you try to set a joint limit outside that range, it won't actually set a limit that will be enforced by the dynamics, but it will report limits that are truncated to the range (-pi,pi).

For example, the double pendulum model has joint limits listed as (-1.30, 1.30), even though they are set to be (-1e16, 1e16).

![bullet_joint_limit.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/412529355-bullet_joint_limit.png)

With this pull request, a helper function is added so that the btHingeConstraint::setLimit function isn't called for invalid joint limits. The joint limits will now be reported as (1, -1), which is bullet's way of saying that no joint limits are active (upper_limit < lower_limit).

I noticed this issue while trying to debug test failures in pull request #2953.
description.html:
BulletHingeJoint doesn't fully support joint limits outside of (-pi,pi). If you try to set a joint limit outside that range, it won't actually set a limit that will be enforced by the dynamics, but it will report limits that are truncated to the range (-pi,pi).

For example, the double pendulum model has joint limits listed as (-1.30, 1.30), even though they are set to be (-1e16, 1e16).

With this pull request, a helper function is added so that the btHingeConstraint::setLimit function isn't called for invalid joint limits. The joint limits will now be reported as (1, -1), which is bullet's way of saying that no joint limits are active (upper_limit < lower_limit).

I noticed this issue while trying to debug test failures in pull request #2953.

title.raw: Improve BulletHingeJoint support for large joint limits
title.html: Improve BulletHingeJoint support for large joint limits
